utterances: Hi.
How are you doing, Neal?
Very well.
Thank you.
I am a former history teacher that has started a cottage industry called Connecticut Cleanout, and I recycle goods from homes.
And I have been getting a lot of foreclosure work.
More than anything else, the resolution of this next big debate may depend on two men: President Obama and House Speaker Boehner.
A-ha.
So, as opposed to picking up the recycling people leave out on their lawn, this is after they sell the house and you going in and look for whatever might be able to be recycled.
Well, people contract with me to either come in and get rid of their stuff.
But I can probably say that I've been 100 percent landfill-free, and I've been able to recycle everything that I have taken thus far.

But in terms of foreclosures, I am seeing an uptick - and this is my first year in business, a pretty good uptake in the amount of calls I've been getting from real state agents for foreclosed cleanouts.
Having moved house few years ago, now, but nevertheless, the amount of stuff one can accumulate is simply astonishing.
Oh, it's out of sight.
I have done jobs where I have filled upward of three 30-yard dumpsters, and I still have not finished.
Wow.
So, it can be quite expensive.
So, given this experience, are you thinking to go back to teaching history?

Well, my three kids want me to because I have been so busy that I'm not spending as much time as I used to with them, and they want me to get back into the classroom, so they can get back their time with their father.
And one final question.
Again, you're dealing with the aftereffects of evictions, a lot of the time, or foreclosures, any bad feelings?
Yeah.
There's - you know, one of the last large cleanouts that I did was at the end of last week.
And it was the family, a very young family, and the couple had twins.
And because of money constraints, they just couldn't keep it together and they ended up splitting up.
And especially with my background as a history teacher, it's very easy to piece together stories.
And, you know, that's not something that I like to see, but, you know, be as it may, it's the business I'm in right now.
Well, continued good luck to you and we'll see how this works out for you.
Thank you very much.
So long.
Here is an e-mail from Eric(ph) in Baltimore: Speaking as somebody who runs an eviction crew and does maintenance on foreclosed houses, business has never been better.
And this is a comment regarding today's show from Emma(ph).
My father owns a home appraisal business.
It suffered greatly when he refused to lower his standards and morals to bend under the pressure of loan officers and banks to provide less-than-legitimate appraisals.
Now, the results of those corrupt appraisals have wrecked havoc on the economy.
And legislation against flaky appraisals is beginning to take effect; his business is beginning to grow again because people recognize his appraiser's work has always been of the highest quality.
He's even been hired to review files for the growing number of legal cases over fraudulent appraisals.
It's wonderful to see his dedication to legal and moral practice be rewarded.
And let's see if we can go to Mark(ph).
And Mark is with us from Wisconsin.
Mark, are you there?
Yes, I am.
Go ahead, please.
Yes.
This is Mark from Wisconsin.
I'm the owner of a business called Archer Lion.
We're a supplier of window siding and doors to builders and remodelers.
And with a single family homebuilding not being what it was a few years ago, we have branched out into senior and assisted living projects, which still seemed to be going very well.
So there are remodeling projects out there available, the business is just changing a little bit?
Yes.

While we still work with remodelers and homebuilders, the senior assisted living memory care units seemed to still be enjoying a real surge as we're all growing older and looking for a place to live and with some maybe extra care.
And do you worry that you're going to take up the slack in this market before the regular market of remodels and new construction get started again?

I really think that, Neal, the senior housing market is so strong and the interest rates are really very moderate that those that are constructing these large senior living complexes are not feeling the downturn that the single-family homebuilder is.
I guess they look at the same demographic numbers that you and I look at and say, there could be a future in this.
Absolutely.
Mark, thanks very much.
Thank you, Neal.
People are digging through their closets, too, in order to make a little money.
Amy Higgins is assistant manager at Plato's Closet in St. Cloud, Minnesota.
They buy and sell used clothing.
And she joins us today from the store.
Nice to have you on TALK OF THE NATION.
Oh, thanks for having me.
And, I guess, your business is up in the past couple of months.
Oh, yes.

We have seen a major increased within probably just the last year in terms of the number of people coming in to sell clothes to us, but also in terms of the number of people buying more clothes from us.
And are the kinds of people the same kind of clientele you usually had over the years?
It stayed fairly consistent, but more so now, we've seen people drive from further distances to our store, such as from South Dakota, North Dakota and the surrounding areas.
And we're also a college-based community, so we see a lot more college students coming in with clothes.
And I guess people come in and tell you why they're there sometimes?
Yeah.
Most of the time it's, you know, college students needing to get home for gas money and people who - college students who need to get groceries.
But also, a lot of people who bring in their clothes and sell them to us turn around and spend the money on cheaper clothes in our store.
And turn - and buy cheaper clothes in your same store?
Yup.
Ah, boy, that's - that can be a little sad, I guess.
Yeah.
I mean, it's hard but it saves the family a lot of money.
We sell things that are, approximately, a third of the retail store's cost.
So, you're saving 60 percent off of an item, basically.
Hmm.
Amy Higgins, thanks very much.
Yeah.
Thank you.
Amy Higgins is the assistant manager of Plato's Closet, used clothing store in St. Cloud, Minnesota, with us by phone today from the store.
You are listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And here's an e-mail that we have from Abigail(ph) in Lawrence, Kansas.
I am blessed to be the owner of a small cosmetics business.
I'm told there is a lipstick indicator on Wall Street.
If it starts going up, it means that the economy is going down.
During the Depression on the three industries really thrived - tobacco, alcohol and cosmetics.
I haven't necessarily seen an upturn, but I'm not worried about losing any business though.
Many women might not want to go out and by a pair of $80 shoes, they are willing to spend 10 bucks on a lipstick.
Let's see if we can get another caller on the line.
And let's go to Kent(ph).
And Kent is calling us from Liberty in Missouri.
